issue.title: tests: Use test framework utils where possible
issue.body:
This PR removes when it is possible the native python assert, and use the test utils function, like `assert_equal`, `assert_greater_than`, `assert_greater_than_or_equal`.

### Update

In addition, this PR includes a new operator `assert_not_equal`, which IMO it is useful to test other conditions and add the error message as a parameter of the function to give more flexibility.

Fixes https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/23119

Edit laanwj: removed HTML comment from post

### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* [#23127](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/23127) (tests: Use assert_equal* utils where possible by vincenzopalazzo)
* [#22867](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/22867) (test: Extend test coverage of BIP125 and document confusing/inconsistent behavior by mjdietzx)
* [#17794](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17794) (test: Use assert_greater_than_or_equal helper method to aid debugging. by jbampton)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.

issue.title: test: Use assert_greater_than_or_equal helper method to aid debugging.
issue.body: Comparisons can be chained arbitrarily, e.g., x < y <= z is equivalent to x < y and y <= z, except that y is evaluated only once (but in both cases z is not evaluated at all when x < y is found to be false).

issue.title: test: Extend test coverage of BIP125 and document confusing/inconsistent behavior
issue.body:
Intention of this PR is to extend test coverage of BIP125. Mostly around [Rule 5](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0125.mediawiki#implementation-details). Focus is on highlighting confusing/inconsistent behavior that I think we need to consider as we move forward with multiple PRs (and different approaches to BIP125 in general) that are under review.

This PR also splits tests out of #22698 (which I've made a draft for now until some related PRs are merged) as they are generally useful and highlight some behavior I think is worth considering.

All that said, I do not see any reason we can't eliminate all these inconsistencies while keeping inherited signaling, which is what #22698 does. But either way, making it clear in tests at least motivates a longer-term fix
